instruction: How did the researchers use machine learning approaches to map individual tree crowns affected by Rapid 'Ohi'a Death (ROD) disease on Hawaii Island?
Output: The researchers used machine learning approaches to map individual tree crowns affected by Rapid 'Ohi'a Death (ROD) disease on Hawaii Island by collecting Laser-Guided Imaging Spectroscopy data and high-resolution digital imagery using the Carnegie Airborne Observatory. They developed a method that utilized an ensemble of two distinct machine learning approaches to identify and map individual tree crowns showing symptoms of both active (brown, desiccated crowns) and past (leafless crowns) ROD infection. The machine learning models were trained to classify and detect these specific crown types based on the collected data. The researchers employed a conservative classification scheme to minimize false-positives and achieved sensitivity rates of 86.9% and 82.5% and precision rates of 97.4% and 95.3% for browning and leafless crowns, respectively. The resulting maps showed the locations of individual crowns suspected of exhibiting the active stage of ROD infection, as well as hotspots of potential ROD incidence across the island. These maps provide valuable information for scientists, administrators, and land managers to understand the spread of ROD and allocate resources effectively to limit its impact.
